headline.main: D.J.'s in Royal Hoax Flee Social Media After Nurse Dies

docs.abstract: The D.J.'s, Mel Greig and Michael Christian of the Sydney station 2Day FM, had duped nurses at King Edward VII Hospital into revealing information about Kate Middleton, the Duchess of Cambridge, who was being treated there for morning sickness.
docs.snippet: The D.J.'s, Mel Greig and Michael Christian of the Sydney station 2Day FM, had duped nurses at King Edward VII Hospital into revealing information about Kate Middleton, the Duchess of Cambridge, who was being treated there for morning sickness.

headline.main: Nurse Who Took Prank Call About Pregnant Duchess Is Found Dead

docs.abstract: A nurse at a London hospital who took a prank call from two Australian radio D.J.s pretending to be British royals was found dead.
docs.snippet: A nurse at a London hospital who took a prank call from two Australian radio D.J.s pretending to be British royals was found dead.

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Defense Authorization Act approved by the Senate promotes equitable treatment of women.
docs.abstract: Editorial holds that the version of National Defense Authorization Act approved by Senate contains two important provisions promoting equitable treatment of women: lifting ban on abortion coverage for female service members in cases of rape and incest, and protecting Afghan women's rights after American troops withdraw; asserts that both measures merit retention in final bill being negotiated by House-Senate committee.
docs.snippet: The National Defense Authorization Act approved by the Senate promotes equitable treatment of women.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: The Royal Pregnancy, and Ailes's Offer to Petraeus

docs.abstract: The news that Kate Middleton is pregnant has already gotten the gears going among news media outlets; the head of Fox News conveyed a message to David H. Petraeus last year encouraging him to run for president; and, a book explores the new golden age of TV.

headline.main: Baby News Keeps Royals in the Headlines

docs.abstract: A royal pregnancy dominated headlines in Britain on Tuesday, giving embattled newspapers something positive to write about and reaffirming the restored popularity of the House of Windsor.

headline.main: Kate Middleton's Morning Sickness: How Bad Can It Get?

docs.abstract: Overwhelming, debilitating nausea when in some antiquated sense, pregnancy is perhaps your main purpose as a public figure? Even non-royal-watchers can sympathize with that.
